content.text:
# Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Limited or Anthology Series or Movie

}}
The Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Limited or Anthology Series or Movie is an award presented annually by the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences (ATAS). It is given in honor of an actress who has delivered an outstanding performance in a leading role on a television limited series or television movie for the primetime network season.
The award was first presented at the 7th Primetime Emmy Awards on March 7, 1955, to Judith Anderson, for her performance as Lady Macbeth on the Hallmark Hall of Fame episode "Macbeth". It has undergone several name changes, with the category split into two categories at the 25th Primetime Emmy Awards: Outstanding Lead Actress in a Special Program – Drama or Comedy; and Outstanding Lead Actress in a Limited Series. By the 31st Primetime Emmy Awards, the categories were merged into one, and it has since undergone several name changes, leading to its current title.
Since its inception, the award has been given to 54 actresses. Cristin Milioti is the current recipient of the award, for her portrayal of Sofia Falcone on The Penguin. Helen Mirren has won the most awards in this category, with four.
Winners and nominations
won for: Hallmark Hall of Fame: Macbeth (1955).]]
won playing Peter Pan in the ''Producers' Showcase (1956).]]
won for Producers' Showcase (1957)]]
won twice for Hallmark Hall of Fame in 1959 and 1962.]]
won twice for Startime (1960) and A Woman Called Golda (1982).]]
won for Ben Casey (1963).]]
won for Bob Hope Presents the Chrysler Theatre (1964).]]
won for ABC Stage 67 (1967) and The Thanksgiving Visitor (1969).]]
won thrice for her roles in My Sweet Charlie (1970), Captains and the Kings (1976), and The Miracle Worker (1979).]]
won for The Neon Ceiling (1971).]]
won for playing Queen Elizabeth I in Elizabeth R (1972).]]
won for A Brand New Life (1973).]]
won playing Jane Pittman in The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman (1974).]]
won for Love Among the Ruins (1975).]]
won for Amy Prentiss (1975).]]
won for See How She Runs (1978) and Do You Remember Love (1985).]]
won for Strangers: The Story of a Mother and Daughter (1979).]]
won for Playing for Time (1980).]]
won for The Thorn Birds (1983).]]
won for The Dollmaker (1984).]]
won twice for The Betty Ford Story (1987)a and Face of a Stranger (1992).]]
won for Foxfire (1987).]]
won for A Killing in a Small Town (1990).]]
won for The Positively True Adventures of the Alleged Texas Cheerleader-Murdering Mom (1993).]]
won for Serving in Silence: The Margarethe Cammermeyer Story (1995)]]
won for Miss Evers' Boys (1997).]]
won for Before Women Had Wings (1998).]]
won for Introducing Dorothy Dandridge (2000)]]
won for Life with Judy Garland: Me and My Shadows (2001)]]
won for My House in Umbria (2003).]]
won twice for Holocaust (1978) and Angels in America (2004).]]
won for Lackawanna Blues (2005).]]
won the award four times for Prime Suspect: Scent of Darkness (1996), The Passion of Ayn Rand (1999), Elizabeth I (2006), and Prime Suspect: The Final Act (2007)]]
won thrice for Wild Iris (2001), John Adams, and The Big C: Hereafter (2013).]]
won the award twice: for her performances in Grey Gardens (2009) and American Horror Story: Coven (2014).]]
won in 2010 for her portrayal of Temple Grandin in the eponymous film.]]
won twice for her roles in Mildred Pierce (2011) and Mare of Easttown (2021)]]
won for her portrayal of Sarah Palin in Game Change (2012)]]
won for Olive Kitteridge (2015)]]
won in 2016 for her portrayal of Marcia Clark in the limited mini-series The People v. O. J. Simpson: American Crime Story.]]
won for Big Little Lies (2017)]]
won twice for Seven Seconds (2018) and Watchmen (2020]]
won for Fosse/Verdon (2019)]]
won for playing Elizabeth Holmes in The Dropout (2022)]]
won for True Detective: Night Country (2024)]]
